ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about material testing and how to characterize different materials in different circumstances. It also helped me apply the knowledge from theoretical materials science courses.
I learned most of this stuff in 285L, but I did not retain any of it. I definitely needed a second pass.

A basic introduction into various concepts in materials science using hands-on labs. Metallurgy, alloys, mechanical properties, crystal structure, microstructure, and characterization using different techniques like SEM and AFM.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I feel we could've been taught more about how to write lab reports and how to work with origin to analyze data rather than go over the concepts which were already learned in MENG 285. It felt very redundant after taking 285. Between class time, and the time spent in lab (going in for extra time as well as the time needed for the final experiment), this course should be 1 credit.
The course is very well organized and designed.
I thought that waiting until the end to grade anything was weird. Otherwise, perfect workload. Maybe bump it up to 1 course credit.

The labs are fun, you do learn about the instruments but most of the lab stuff are done by TAs for you. The short lab reports aren't too bad but they're uneven in workload, and it's never really clear how in-depth you need to go. Having group lab reports has its ups and downs; properly splitting the workload is a challenge at times. In-class lectures are okay, a bit on the challenging side though, particularly if you haven't taken 285. The entire class has only two graded assignments: the final presentation and the final report, so it's pretty stressful by the time finals comes around.
WAYYYYYYY too much work on the back end for a 0.5 credit course. I mean WAYYYYYYYYY too much. Needs better equipment!!!! This is not the professors fault, this lies on Yales shoulders.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially if you're interested in materials science try to take it earlier.

If you're interested in materials science, this would be a good course, though I recommend maybe taking 285 before; lacking the basic knowledge behind the concepts in this course is tough, even though they're kind of touched on in the in-class lectures, you still need to do quite a bit of reading and catching up outside of class. Prof Amit is kinda polarizing, you'll either like him or won't, but by the end of the course, you'll be pretty great at writing lab reports using published literature, and you'll know a good bit of experiment-backed materials science knowledge.
NO; not worth 0.5 credits at all for the workload.
